column12: non-toxic and non-immunogenic, with little or no bonding or integration with the body.

column11: being absorbed or excreted as it performs its function, often eliminating the need for removal.

column6: A high-aspect-ratio morphological form of a material characterized by a length significantly greater than its diameter.

column11: SI unit for specific strength is Pa⋅m3/kg, or N⋅m/kg, which is dimensionally equivalent to m2/s2, In fiber or textile applications, tenacity is the usual measure of specific strength
produced through biological synthesis processes like Biological growth, morphogenesis, secretion etc.
produced through industrial syntesis processes like Chemical extraction, fermentation, or polymerization

column6: The formation of chemical bonds (covalent or ionic) that link one polymer chain to another.
A role of a material that is added to another material in trace amounts to alter electric/optic/structural properties of the doped material.
the longest continuous sequence of covalently bonded atoms within a macromolecular structure that provides the primary structural framework
an atom or group of atoms covalently bonded to the backbone of a polymer chain but not part of the primary structural spine or backbone
A polymer or oligomer whose molecules are capable of entering into further polymerization through reactive groups to reach a higher molecular weight state.
A polymer derived from more than one species of monomer.
A molecular complex that consists of a few monomer units (intermediate between a monomer and a polymer)
A solid or highly viscous substance of plant or synthetic origin that is typically convertible into polymers.
A compound that participates in a chemical reaction that produces another compound.
steel is a ferrous metal that consists of iron and carbon and possibly other alloying elements (and possibly impurities).
ferrous metal that has a limited amout of carbon
stainless steel is an iron-based alloy that contains chromium, making it resistant to corrosion (rust).
metal that has iron as primary constituent
ferrous metal that has an amout of min 2.07 wt % carbon
a metallic alloy is a mixture of chemical elements of which at least one is a metallic element

chromium steel is the name for any one of a class of non-stainless steels which are used for applications such as bearings, tools, drills and utensils. Such as stainless steel, chromium steels contain chromium, but do not have the corrosion-resistant properties of stainless steel.
steel with tailored mechanical properties
alloy steel is steel that is alloyed with a variety of elements in amounts between 1.0% and 50% by weight, typically to improve its mechanical properties.
non-ferrous metals are metals or alloys that do not contain iron (allotropes of iron, ferrite, and so on) in appreciable amounts.
non-ferrous metal consisting primarily of aluminium mixed with other elements

precious metal consisting primarily of gold
precious metal consisting primarily of silver
precious metal consisting primarily of platinum
precious metal consisting primarily of palladium
precious metal consisting primarily of rhodium

Biodegradable polymers are polymers that have the biodegradability disposition. They can be decomposed by biological organisms into environmentally benign substances (carbon dioxide and methane, mineral salts or new biomass) in a non-harmful timescale.
A thermoplastic is a polymer that becomes moldable when heated and solidifies upon cooling.

poylethylen is a thermoplastic polymer produced by polymerization of the monomer ethylene including further crosslinking and modifications using other comonomers; it excludes ultra hight molecular polyethylen.
column10: ('output of' some (polymerization and 'has input' some ('ethylene group' and 'has role' some 'polymerisation monomer')))

column6: High-Density polyethylene is a polyethylene that is characterized by a linear molecular structure and high density.
Linear low-density polyethylene is a polyethylene that is distinguished by its linear backbone with short-chain branching.
Low-Density polyethylene is a polyethylene that is characterized by a branched molecular structure and low density.
poylpropylene is a thermoplastic polymer produced by polymerization of the monomer propylene including further crosslinking and modifications using other comonomers
column11: this excludes ultra hight molecular polyethylen because very high molecular weight polyethylene is not thermoplastic anymore

column6: Atactic polypropylene is a polypropylene in which the methyl groups are randomly distributed along the polymer chain.
Isotactic polypropylene is a polypropylene in which all the methyl groups are aligned on the same side of the polymer chain.
Syndiotactic polypropylene is a polypropylene in which the methyl groups alternate regularly along the polymer chain.
polyvinyl chloride is a thermoplastic polymer produced by polymerization of the monomer vinyl chloride.
column11: they are usualy hard or soft and flexible with incrased use of plasticisers.

column6: Flexible PVC is a polyvinyl chloride that has been modified with plasticizers to impart flexibility.
Rigid PVC is a polyvinyl chloride that is characterized by its stiffness and durability.
Polystyrene is a thermoplastic polymer produced by polymerization of the aromatic hydrocarbon styrene
General purpose polystyrene is a polystyrene that is valued for its clarity and ease of processing.
High impact polystyrene is a polystyrene that is modified with rubber to improve its impact resistance.
Polyethylene terephthalate is a thermoplastic polyester produced by polycondensation of ethylene glycol and terephthalate precursors.
column14: it is the dominant polyester utilized in global packaging and fiber applications

column6: Amorphous PET is a polyethylene terephthalate that is characterized by a non-crystalline structure.
Crystalline PET is a polyethylene terephthalate that is distinguished by its ordered, crystalline structure.
A biodegradable thermolpastic polyester polymer; synthesized via the polycondensation of succinic acid and 1,4-butanediol.
Polylactic acid is a biodegradable polymer produced from renewable resources such as corn starch.
polyhydroxyalkanoates are biodegradable polymers that are biosynthesized by microorganisms from sugars or lipids.
Thermosetting polymer is a polymer that, once cured, irreversibly sets into a permanent shape.
column10: ('output of' some curing)

column6: Epoxy resins are epoxide-functional oligomers curing via ring-opening into crosslinked thermoset networks.
column14: they are utilized for high-performance structural adhesives, composite matrices, and protective coatings.

column6: Bisphenol a epoxy is an epoxy resin that is formulated using bisphenol a to enhance its mechanical properties.
Novolac epoxy is an epoxy resin that is based on novolac resins to provide improved thermal and chemical resistance.
Phenolic resins are thermosetting polymers synthesized via condensation of phenol and formaldehyde
column11: they form rigid, char-forming crosslinked networks
column14: they are utilized for flame-resistant adhesives, friction materials, and molded components

column6: Phenol-Formaldehyde resin is a phenolic resin that is synthesized from phenol and formaldehyde.
Melamine resin is a thermosetting aminoplast polymer synthesized via condensation
column11: they form hard, durable crosslinked networks.
column14: they are widely used in decorative laminates, kitchenware, and coating crosslinkers.

column6: A thermosetting polymer with carbamate crosslinks.
column14: offers high versatility in mechanical properties

column6: Unsaturated polyester resin is a thermosetting polymer system of unsaturated polyester prepolymers in reactive vinyl monomers; it cures by radical crosslinking into rigid networks.
column14: they are used for fiber-reinforced composites

column6: Urea formaldehyde is a thermosetting polymer formed from urea and formaldehyde, commonly used in adhesives and molding compounds.
An elastomer is a polymer that exhibits elasticity by returning to its original shape after deformation.
Natural rubber is an elastomer polymer, and a biopolymer harvested as plant latex; consisting of cis-1,4-polyisoprene chains; typically sulfur-vulcanized to create crosslinks between chains.
column11: they are predominantly cis-1,4-polyisoprene,
column14: they are used widely in Heavy-duty truck tires

column6: Synthetic rubber is an elastomer that is produced through chemical synthesis to mimic natural rubber’s properties.

Styrene–butadiene rubber is a synthetic rubber, and is a family of synthetic random copolymer elastomers of styrene and butadiene, made by emulsion or solution polymerization and typically vulcanized.
column14: used widely for its good abrasion resistance and tunable hardness, for instance in tire treads.

column6: Silicone rubber is a synthetic rubber, and is a crosslinked polysiloxane elastomer family, with organic side groups.
column11: it is available in multiple formulations and often filled.
column12: widely used for its broad service temperature range in medical devices, gaskets, and culinary tools

column6: Polychloroprene is a synthetic rubber, and is a family of synthetic elastomeric rubbers; synthesised typically through emulsion polymerization of chloroprene
column11: it offers good weathering and ozone resistance.
column12: it is widely used in gaskets and wetsuits.

column6: nitrile butadiene rubber is a synthetic rubber, and is a family of synthetic acrylonitrile–butadiene copolymer elastomers
column11: it can have tunable polarity and oil/fuel resistance
column12: it is widely used in oil/fuel resistance applicaitons such as seals, fuel hoses, and protective gloves

column6: Ethylene propylene diene monomer is a synthetic rubber produced from ethylene, propylene, and a diene monomer
column11: it offers excellent weather resistance

column6: Amorphous metal glass is glass that is characterized by a disordered, non-crystalline atomic structure, resembling a frozen liquid.
Iron-based metallic glass is an amorphous metal glass that is predominantly composed of iron.
Magnesium-based metallic glass is an amorphous metal glass that is primarily composed of magnesium, noted for its low density.
Zirconium-based metallic glass is an amorphous metal glass that is composed mainly of zirconium, valued for its corrosion resistance and strength.
Bioactive glass is a specialty glass that forms a biologically compatible hydroxycarbonate apatite (HCA) layer on its surface in physiological conditions
column11: enables bonding with bone tissue.

column6: Chalcogenide glass is a non‑silicate glass (generally non‑oxide) that contains one or more chalcogens
column11: Chalcogens such as sulfur, selenium, or tellurium as key constituents. Is valued particularly for infrared transparency.

column6: Chemically strengthened glass is a specialty glass that is treated via chemical processes to enhance its strength.
column10: ('is specified output of' some hardening)

column6: Conductive glass is functional glass that has been modified to exhibit electrical conductivity.

column5: ('glass' and ('part of' some (object and ('has function' some function))))
column6: Functional glass is advanced glass that is designed to perform specific roles beyond conventional optical applications.
column11: axiom is related to functional material

column6: Electrochromic glass is a specialty glass that can reversibly change its light transmission properties when an electrical voltage is applied.
Photochromic glass is a specialty glass that alters its optical properties in response to exposure to light.
Thermochromic glass is a specialty glass that changes its optical properties as a function of temperature.

column5: (glass and ('is specified output of' some 'ion-exchange hardening'))
column6: Ion-Exchanged glass is a form of chemically strengthened glass that is produced by exchanging ions to improve durability.
Magnetic glass is a specialty glass that exhibits intrinsic bulk magnetic behavior|Magnetic glass is functional glass that is modified to exhibit magnetic properties.
column11: Its composition and/or microstructure contains a significant population of magnetic species - typically transition‑metal or rare‑earth ions and/or magnetic nanophases - so that magnetic susceptibility/permeability/magnetization is a designed functional property of the glass.

column6: Non‑silicate glasses are glasses whose primary glass‑forming network is not based on SiO₂
column11: Based on other glass formers or non‑oxide systems (e.g., phosphate (P₂O₅)-based, fluoride-based, or chalcogenide (S/Se/Te)-based compositions).

column6: Borate glass is a non‑silicate glass based primarily on boron oxide (B₂O₃) as the glass‑forming network
column11: It is distinct from borosilicate glass because B₂O₃ is the primary network former here rather than an added co‑former in a silica‑based network.

column6: Borate-based bioactive glass is a bioactive glass that is formulated with borate compounds to promote biological interaction.
Germanate glass is a non-silicate glass that is composed primarily of germanium oxide, noted for its infrared transmission.
Phosphate glass is a non‑silicate glass based primarily on phosphorus pentoxide (P₂O₅)
column11: (P₂O₅) as the glass former (i.e., replacing SiO₂ as the network basis).

column6: Phosphate-based bioactive glass is a bioactive glass that is composed predominantly of phosphate compounds.
Optical glass is a specialty glass manufactured for optical components
column10: ('has characteristic' some 'refraction (optical)')
column11: composition and processing chosen to achieve specified optical/mechanical parameters such as refractive index and dispersion.
column12: e.g., lenses, prisms, mirrors

column6: Crown glass is an optical glass that is characterized by its low dispersion and high clarity.
Flint glass is an optical glass that is distinguished by its high refractive index and dispersion.
Fused silica glass is an optical glass that is made from pure silica, prized for its high transparency and thermal stability.|Fused silica is a silicate glass that is essentially pure, amorphous SiO₂

column5: ('optical glass' and ('has characteristic' some 'nonlinear optical property'))
column6: A functional glass that is engineered to display nonlinear optical responses under intense light.
Silicate glasses are glasses whose network is based primarily on silica (SiO₂)
Aluminosilicate glass is a silicate glass in which SiO₂ and Al₂O₃ are key structural units
column11: typically higher transformation/softening temperatures and improved mechanical/chemical performance compared with many common silicates

column6: Aluminosilicate gorilla glass is a chemically strengthened glass that is enhanced with an aluminosilicate composition for superior scratch resistance.
column10: ('is specified output of' some hardening)

column6: High-Temperature resistant glass is an aluminosilicate glass that is engineered to maintain stability at elevated temperatures.
Borosilicate glass is a silicate glass that uses boron trioxide (B₂O₃) as a major additional glass‑forming constituent
column11: characteristically low thermal expansion and high thermal/chemical resistance compared with soda‑lime glass.

column6: Cobalt-borosilicate glass is a magnetic glass that is formulated with cobalt to enhance its magnetic properties.
Iron-borosilicate glass is a magnetic glass that incorporates iron and borosilicate compounds to display magnetic behavior.
Pyrex-type glass is a form of borosilicate glass that is renowned for its high resistance to thermal shock.
Fused silica is a silicate glass that is essentially pure, amorphous SiO₂
column10: ('is specified output of' some 'cooling')
column11: obtained by melting silica and cooling fast enough to avoid crystallization.
column12: often called fused quartz or vitreous silica

column6: Lead glass is a silicate glass in which lead(II) oxide (PbO) is incorporated in significant amounts
column11: increased refractive index and modified working properties relative to ordinary silicate glasses

column6: Barium glass is a form of lead glass that is modified with barium oxide to alter its optical properties.
Potash lead glass is a form of lead glass that utilizes potash as a flux in addition to lead oxide.
Silicate-based bioactive glass is a bioactive glass that is composed primarily of silicate compounds to facilitate bonding with biological tissue.
S53P4 Bioglass is a silicate-based bioactive glass formulated with a distinct composition for enhanced bioactivity.
45S5 Bioglass is a silicate-based bioactive glass with a specific composition known for its ability to bond with bone.
Soda‑lime glass is a silicate glass that is composed of about 70% silica (SiO₂) with soda (Na₂O) and lime (CaO)
column10: ('has part' some 'calcium oxide' and 'has part' some 'sodium hydroxide')
column11: soda (Na₂O) acting as a flux and lime (CaO) acting as a stabilizer
column12: widely used as common window and container glass.

column6: Specialty glasses are glasses engineered primarily for a targeted functional performance profile
Tellurite glass is a nonlinear optical glass that is formulated with tellurium oxide to achieve a high refractive index and nonlinear properties.

column5: (glass and ('is specified output of' some hardening))
column6: Toughened glass is a specialty glass that is mechanically treated to increase its strength and safety.
Laminated glass is a specialty glass that is composed of multiple bonded layers to improve safety and acoustic performance.
column10: ('part of' some 'laminated composite')

column6: Fluoride glass is a non‑silicate glass made from metal fluorides (a non‑oxide glass family)
column11: Often used for photonics because certain compositions offer good infrared transmission and low phonon energies.

column6: Glass‑ceramics are inorganic, non‑metallic material prepared by controlled crystallization of glasses via different processing methods; they contain at least one type of functional crystalline phase and a residual glass, and the crystallized volume fraction may vary from ppm to almost 100%.

column6: Leucite-Based glass-ceramics are glass-ceramics that are non-clay ceramics containing leucite crystals to enhance thermal and mechanical properties.
Lithium disilicate glass-ceramics are glass-ceramics that contain lithium disilicate crystals to provide high strength and aesthetic appeal.

column6: Transparent glass-ceramics are glass-ceramics that are engineered to maintain optical transparency despite partial crystallization.

column6: oxide ceramic consisting primarily of aluminium oxide
Barium titanate is a dielectric ceramic that is an electroceramic composed of barium, titanium, and oxygen, noted for its ferroelectric properties.
Beryllia is an oxide ceramic that is an advanced ceramic composed of beryllium oxide, valued for its high thermal conductivity and electrical insulation.

column3: bismuth strontium calcium copper oxide ceramic
column6: Bismuth strontium calcium copper oxide is a superconducting ceramic that is composed of bismuth, strontium, calcium, copper, and oxygen, featuring a layered crystal structure.
Hydroxyapatite is a bioactive ceramic that is composed of calcium phosphate and closely resembles the mineral component of bone.
Lead zirconate titanate is a dielectric ceramic that is an electroceramic composed of lead, zirconium, and titanium, renowned for its piezoelectric behavior.
oxide ceramic consisting primarily of magnesium oxide
oxide ceramic consisting primarily of silicon oxide
Aluminosilicates are silicate ceramics that consist of aluminum and silicon oxides.
Kaolinite is an aluminosilicate that is a silicate ceramic based on the mineral kaolinite, valued for its fine particle size and plasticity.
Mullite is an aluminosilicate that is a silicate ceramic known for its excellent high-temperature stability.
Clay-based ceramics are silicate ceramics that are formed from natural clays.
column10: ('is specified output of' some ('manufacturing process' and ('has specified input' some clay)))

column6: Titania is an oxide ceramic that is an advanced ceramic composed of titanium dioxide, used for its photocatalytic and pigment properties.
Yttrium barium copper oxide is a superconducting ceramic that is composed of yttrium, barium, copper, and oxygen, notable for its high critical temperature.
oxide ceramic consisting primarily of zirconium oxide
Magnesia-Stabilized zirconia is a zirconia that is an oxide ceramic stabilized with magnesia to improve its thermal stability.
Yttria-Stabilized zirconia is a zirconia that is an oxide ceramic stabilized with yttria to enhance its thermal and mechanical performance.
ceramic consisting primarily of non-oxide elements

carbide ceramic with silicon
carbide ceramic with tungsten
Boron carbide is a carbide ceramic that is a non-oxide ceramic composed of boron and carbon, known for its remarkable hardness and low density.
non-oxide ceramic consisting of a metal and nitrogen
nitritde with silicon
nitritde with boron
Aluminum nitride is a nitride ceramic that is a non-oxide ceramic composed of aluminum and nitrogen, prized for its high thermal conductivity.
non-oxide ceramic consisting of a boron and another element
Titanium diboride is a boride ceramic that is a non-oxide ceramic composed of titanium and boron, valued for its high hardness and melting point.
Zirconium diboride is a boride ceramic that is a non-oxide ceramic composed of zirconium and boron, known for its excellent thermal conductivity and stability.
non-oxide ceramic consisting of a silicon and another element

column5: (ceramic and 'has disposition' some (bioactive or bioinert or bioresorbable))
column6: Bioceramics are ceramics that are engineered to be compatible with biological systems.
Bioactive ceramics are bioceramics that interact with biological tissues to promote bonding or regeneration.
Bioresorbable ceramics are bioceramics that are designed to gradually be resorbed and replaced by natural tissue.
Bioinert ceramics are bioceramics that are designed to remain inert in biological environments to minimize adverse reactions.

column5: (ceramic and ('has disposition' some     (superconducting or 'dielectric disposition' or 'magnetic property')))
column6: Electroceramics are ceramics that are specifically engineered for electrical, magnetic, or superconducting applications.
Dielectric ceramics are electroceramics that serve primarily as electrical insulators due to their high dielectric constants.
Magnetic ceramics are electroceramics that exhibit magnetic properties, typically based on iron oxides combined with other metal oxides.
Superconducting ceramics are electroceramics that exhibit zero electrical resistance below a critical temperature.

column5: (ceramic and ('is specified output of' some 'conventional ceramics manufacturing'))
column6: Natural ceramics (traditional ceramics) are ceramics that are produced using conventional methods with natural raw materials such as clay and silica.
Earthenware is a clay-based ceramic that is formed at relatively low temperatures, resulting in a porous, rustic material.
Non-Clay ceramics are traditional ceramics that are formed from raw materials other than clay.
Fritted ceramics are non-clay ceramics that are manufactured by fusing and subsequently grinding glass materials.
Porcelain is a clay-based ceramic that is distinguished by its translucency, strength, and refined appearance.

column6: Stoneware is a clay-based ceramic that is fired at higher temperatures than earthenware to yield a denser, more durable material.
Technical ceramics (advanced ceramics) are ceramics that are engineered for high-performance applications.
A composite is an object aggregate that consists of two or more bonded materials with dissimilar physical or chemical properties where the parts remain seperate and distinct in the aggregate.

Alumina matrix composites are oxide-oxide composites that use alumina as the primary matrix reinforced by secondary oxide phases.
Zirconia matrix composites are oxide-oxide composites that use zirconia as the primary matrix reinforced by additional oxide phases.
